newsitem.title: USA: U.S. judge bars Boston muni firm in COPs case.
newsitem.headline: U.S. judge bars Boston muni firm in COPs case.

text.p: A Massachusetts federal court permanently barred a Boston municipal bond firm and one of its officials from violating federal securities laws in an action involving $14 million in certificates of participation (COPs), the SEC announced on Tuesday.

Judge Reginald Lindsay of the U.S.District Court for the District of Massachusetts charged that Robert Gersh, Boston Municipal Securities, Inc. (BMS), and Devonshire Escrow and Transfer Corp. fraudulently offered the so-called COPs.
Gersh, BMS, and Devonshire consented to the order without admitting or denying the allegations, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.
Gersh also was ordered to return roughly $7.5 million. But about $5.9 million was waived because Gersh is unable to pay, SEC said.
SEC alleged that the defendants misappropriated over $7 million in investor funds. Eight Gersh COPs issues totaling $7.2 million, have defaulted, SEC said.
The court previously granted a temporary restraining order and asset freeze against the defendants, the appointment of a receiver, and a preliminary injunction against the defendants.
